docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Forgotten Domestic Crisis,'' by Marcia Angell (Op-Ed, Oct. 13): As a psychotherapist with many patients in their 20's, I can attest to the fact that not only do most of them not have any health insurance, but they also do not expect it as a condition of living in this country.

More excerpts are online at nytimes.com/nyregion. Q. Let's start with the budget. . . . Outline for us $5 billion in savings.

headline.main: Golisano's Vision of Government: Leaner, More Efficient and Less Invasive

docs.abstract: Excerpts from The New York Times interview with New York gubernatorial candidate Tom Golisano
docs.snippet: Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday with Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate for governor, conducted by several editors and reporters of The New York Times. More excerpts are online at nytimes.com/nyregion.    Q. Let's start...
docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate for governor, said yesterday that he would close the state's looming budget deficit by pushing some people off Medicaid, limiting others from signing up and holding the line on financing for education. He said stern measures were needed to avert tax increases that he said would block economic revitalization. Serious budget reduction must start with Medicaid and education because they are the state's two costliest programs, he said. But, he said, such proposals are ''not going to make a lot of people happy.''

headline.main: Golisano Proposes Stern Measures to Close Budget Gap and Avoid Tax Rise

docs.abstract: Independence Party gubernatorial candidate Tom Golisano says he would close New York's looming budget deficit by tightening Medicaid eligibility and holding line on education funding, in order to avoid tax increases that would hinder economic revitalization; discusses campaign positions in interview at The New York Times; photos; promises non-nonsense corporate executive's approach intolerant of back-room dealing and quid pro quos; Golisano also would push for free SUNY tuition for high school students with at least B averages, using $1.4 billion from lottery (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cigna reported more losses today for its reinsurance business, creating a total of more than $1 billion in third-quarter costs. A recent arbitration ruling in New York led to a $315 million charge related to losses in a business that has been inactive for two years. Reinsurance involves insurers selling and buying parts of competitors' policies to spread out the risk.

headline.main: More Losses in Cigna Reinsurance Unit

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Marcia Angell (Op-Ed, Oct. 13) is correct when she says the health care system ''would be front and center in this fall's political debate'' were it not for national defense issues and a looming war with Iraq crowding political agendas. Why can't we kill two birds with one stone? Why not have a quid pro quo health care system?

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress called it quits today, as both parties gambled that they would be in a stronger legislative position next month after the elections that will determine control of the House and Senate. Lawmakers, who had joined together after the Sept. 11 attacks, recessed to campaign after the drive to create a new agency to combat terror threats died in recriminations over the motives of each side.

headline.main: Senate Follows House on the Road Out of Washington and Plans to Return on Nov. 12

docs.abstract: Senate calls it quits on heels of House recess, leaving raft of legislation unresolved until return on Nov 12; both parties sieze on logjam as campaign issue; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Congress called it quits today, as both parties gambled that they would be in a stronger legislative position next month after the elections that will determine control of the House and Senate.    Lawmakers, who had joined together after the Sept. 11...

byline.original: By CARL HULSE and DAVID FIRESTONE

docs.lead_paragraph: The Port Gibson Oil Mill died in June. The steam whistle that once summoned all 50 workers at 7 every morning -- and woke everyone else in town -- is silent. The day-and-night din of machines crushing cottonseeds is gone, and with it the comforting odor of the seeds cooking. The big tractor trailers have all moved on. The mill ran for 120 years, which townspeople say is longer than any other cotton-oil mill anywhere. It was the town's biggest private employer, its biggest taxpayer and the last vestige of an industry that once made Port Gibson one of the richest little towns in America. Shutting it down, said Emma Crisler, editor and publisher of the weekly Port Gibson Reveille, ''is like losing a piece of your soul.''

headline.main: A Vestige of King Cotton Fades Out in Mississippi

docs.abstract: Port Gibson, Miss, lost its biggest employer when Archer Daniels Midland Co shut down town's 120-year-old cottonseed-oil mill in June; now residents are trying to thwart mills' demolition, searching for someone to revive it or at least get Archer Daniels to donate buildings to town; map; photo (M)
